DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text name of a measure that is not part of the protocol or treatment program regimen.  Concomitant procedures are performed in response to preexisting conditions/symptoms, or to treat adverse events.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Measure that is not part of the protocol or treatment program regimen.  Concomitant procedures are performed in response to preexisting conditions/symptoms, or to treat adverse events.

Concepts.definition: Accessory, accompanying especially in a subordinate or incidental way, occurring or existing during the same period of time.
An unspecified technique.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Tests, examinations, evaluations used to determine a subject's status or response to intervention.
ConceptualDomain.changeDescription: Created initially to support CCR value domain for CTMS.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Text names of procedures that are not part of the protocol regimen.  Concomitant procedures are used for treatment of preexisting conditions or symptoms, and for adverse events. [Manually-curated]

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Practices not generally recognized by the medical community as standard or conventional medical approaches and used to replace, enhance or complement standard treatments. Complementary medicine includes dietary supplements, megadose vitamins, herbal preparations, special teas, acupuncture, massage therapy, magnet therapy, spiritual healing, and meditation.

Concepts.definition: A group of diverse medical and health care systems, practices, and products that are not presently considered to be part of conventional medicine. Complementary medicine as being used together with conventional medicine, whereas alternative medicine is used in place of conventional medicine. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) groups CAM practices into four domains, recognizing there can be some overlap: mind-body medicine; biologically based practices, manipulative and body-based practices, and energy medicine. In addition, NCCAM studies CAM whole medical systems, which cut across all domains.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that collects a component of the peripheral blood while returning the rest to the donor.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that collects a component of the peripheral blood while returning the rest to the donor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The prevention of conception or impregnation by the use of devices or drugs or surgery.

Concepts.definition: The prevention of conception or impregnation by the use of devices or drugs or surgery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Washing out the bronchi and alveoli by flushing with a fluid.

Concepts.definition: Washing out the bronchi and alveoli by flushing with a fluid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (KAW-ter-ih-ZAY-shun) The destruction of tissue with a hot instrument, an electrical current, or a caustic substance.

Concepts.definition: To destroy tissue using a hot or cold instrument, an electrical current, or a chemical that burns or dissolves the tissue. This process may be used to kill certain types of small tumors or to seal off blood vessels to stop bleeding.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Venous Access Device Removal
A particular course of action intended to achieve a result.: Pertaining to a tooth or teeth, or to odontology.

Concepts.definition: An activity that produces an effect, or that is intended to alter the course of a disease in a patient or population. This is a general term that encompasses the medical, social, behavioral, and environmental acts that can have preventive, therapeutic, or palliative effects.
Pertaining to a tooth or teeth, or to odontology.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No value exists.

Concepts.definition: No value exists.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No value exists.

Concepts.definition: No value exists.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Oxygen that is at an atmospheric pressure higher than the pressure at sea level.  Breathing hyperbaric oxygen to enhance the effectiveness of radiation therapy is being studied.

Concepts.definition: Oxygen that is administered at a higher pressure compared to standard (i.e. sea-level) atmospheric pressure.  Administration of oxygen under hyperbaric conditions enhances the delivery of oxygen to hypoxic tumor cells, thereby increasing their sensitivity to radiation and chemotherapy.  In addition, hyperbaric oxygen may improve the healing of radiation-induced injuries by improving oxygen delivery to damaged tissue. (NCI04)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Devices that provide support for tubular structures that are being anastomosed or for body cavities during skin grafting.

Concepts.definition: Devices that provide support for tubular structures that are being anastomosed or for body cavities during skin grafting.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure where a cut is made in a tissue or structure to allow the drainage of fluid.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure where a cut is made in a tissue or structure to allow the drainage of fluid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A drainage tube. A surgeon implants or creates a shunt to divert blood or other fluid from one part of the body to another part. For example, a surgeon may implant a tube to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain to the abdomen. Or a surgeon may divert normal blood flow by joining two blood vessels together.: The right to obtain or make use of or take advantage of something (as services or membership); the right to enter.  Also, an act or means of approaching.: No Value Exists

Concepts.definition: A drainage tube. A surgeon implants or creates a shunt to divert blood or other fluid from one part of the body to another part. For example, a surgeon may implant a tube to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain to the abdomen. Or a surgeon may divert normal blood flow by joining two blood vessels together.
The right to obtain or make use of or take advantage of something (as services or membership); the right to enter.  Also, an act or means of approaching.
Located within a ventricle of the brain or heart.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No value exists.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Devices used to deliver air, oxygen, or a mixture of the two gases containing aerosol particles to the patient's airway. Air-oxygen masks used for aerosol administration are typically connected to the gas source with wide bore tubing and include head straps for stabilization. The devices are typically made of plastic.

Concepts.definition: Devices used to deliver air, oxygen, or a mixture of the two gases containing aerosol particles to the patient's airway. Air-oxygen masks used for aerosol administration are typically connected to the gas source with wide bore tubing and include head straps for stabilization. The devices are typically made of plastic.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Insertion of a thin needle or tube into the abdomen to remove fluid from the peritoneal cavity.

Concepts.definition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from any body cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pleurodesis

Concepts.definition: (PLOO-ro-DEE-sis) A surgical  procedure that causes the membranes around the lung to stick together and prevents the buildup of fluid in the space between the membranes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The participant became menopausal through some form of radiation treatment
No value exists.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stent/Catheter Change
Used for operative procedures on organs, regions, or tissues in the treatment of diseases, including tissue section by lasers. It excludes transplantation, for which "transplantation" is used.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or treatment procedure performed by manual and/or instrumental means, often involving an incision and the removal or replacement of a diseased organ or tissue; of or relating to or involving or used in surgery or requiring or amenable to treatment by surgery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from the thoracic cavity.

Concepts.definition: The removal of excess fluid via needle puncture from the thoracic cavity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Venous Access Device Placement
A technique in which a hollow, flexible tube is used to drain body fluids or to introduce fluids into the body, or to examine or widen a narrowed vein or artery.

Concepts.definition: A technique in which a hollow, flexible tube is used to drain body fluids or to introduce fluids into the body, or to examine or widen a narrowed vein or artery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Direct Current Cardioversion
Packed red blood cell transfusion

Concepts.definition: The intravenous administration of red blood cells (whole blood without the plasma) into an individual.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The infusion of platelets into the bloodstream.

Concepts.definition: The infusion of platelets into the bloodstream.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

Concepts.definition: Surgical removal of approximately half of the colon.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A therapeutic procedure used in patients with kidney failure.  It involves the extracorporeal removal of harmful wastes and fluids from the blood using a dialysis machine.  Following the dialysis, the blood is returned to the body.

Concepts.definition: A therapeutic procedure used in patients with kidney failure.  It involves the extracorporeal removal of harmful wastes and fluids from the blood using a dialysis machine.  Following the dialysis, the blood is returned to the body.

Removal of a medical device implanted in an artery for the delivery of medication, fluids, nutrition, or other ordered treatment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Continuous Veno-Venous Hemofiltration (CVVH)

Into or within a vein. Intravenous usually refers to a way of giving a drug or other substance through a needle or tube inserted into a vein.: The process of combining with water. In medicine, the process of giving fluids needed by the body.

Concepts.definition: Into or within a vein. Intravenous usually refers to a way of giving a drug or other substance through a needle or tube inserted into a vein.
The chemical process by which a molecular entity reacts with both the hydroxyl group (-OH) and proton (H+) found in a water molecule.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The infusion of plasma into the bloodstream.

Concepts.definition: The infusion of plasma into the bloodstream.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Pulmonary Function Test Forced Vital Capacity

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Pulmonary Function Test Forced Vital Capacity
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A broad range of tests that are performed to assess how well lungs inhale and exhale air and how efficiently they transfer oxygen into the blood.: The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after forced maximum inhalation.

Concepts.definition: A broad range of tests that are performed to assess how well lungs inhale and exhale air and how efficiently they transfer oxygen into the blood.
The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after forced maximum inhalation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Magnetic resonance imaging done from inside the rectum that usually utilizes a surface coil within a latex balloon to generate the magnetic field.

Concepts.definition: Magnetic resonance imaging done from inside the rectum that usually utilizes a surface coil within a latex balloon to generate the magnetic field.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure to remove dead tissue or foreign material from a wound to expose underlying healthy tissue and to promote healing.

Concepts.definition: A procedure to remove dead tissue or foreign material from a wound to expose underlying healthy tissue and to promote healing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure in which an opening is made in the pericardium.

Concepts.definition: A procedure in which an opening is made in the pericardium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Having to do with urine or the organs of the body that produce and get rid of urine.: A technique in which a hollow, flexible tube is used to drain body fluids or to introduce fluids into the body, or to examine or widen a narrowed vein or artery.

Concepts.definition: Urinary; of or relating to urine, of or relating to the urinary system, or of or relating to the function or production or secretion of urine.
A technique in which a hollow, flexible tube is used to drain body fluids or to introduce fluids into the body, or to examine or widen a narrowed vein or artery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive procedure in which a hollow needle is introduced through an intervertebral space in the lower back to access the subarachnoid space in order to sample cerebrospinal fluid or to administer medication.

Concepts.definition: An invasive procedure in which a hollow needle is introduced through an intervertebral space in the lower back to access the subarachnoid space in order to sample cerebrospinal fluid or to administer medication.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Personal performance of activities or tasks traditionally performed by professional health care providers.: A technique in which a hollow, flexible tube is used to drain body fluids or to introduce fluids into the body, or to examine or widen a narrowed vein or artery.

Concepts.definition: Personal performance of activities or tasks traditionally performed by professional health care providers.
A technique in which a hollow, flexible tube is used to drain body fluids or to introduce fluids into the body, or to examine or widen a narrowed vein or artery.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Use of an incentive spirometer to take slow, deep breaths, and maximize lung capacity. Visual feedback from the spirometer is designed to help the user execute sustained maximal inhalations.

Concepts.definition: Use of an incentive spirometer to take slow, deep breaths, and maximize lung capacity. Visual feedback from the spirometer is designed to help the user execute sustained maximal inhalations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A treatment that involves injection of local anesthetic and alcohol to the celiac plexus, causing temporary degeneration of the nerve fibers. The procedure is performed in an effort to alleviate intractable pain, generally caused by cancer or chronic pancreatitis.

Concepts.definition: A treatment that involves injection of local anesthetic and alcohol to the celiac plexus, causing temporary degeneration of the nerve fibers. The procedure is performed in an effort to alleviate intractable pain, generally caused by cancer or chronic pancreatitis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of fingers to evacuate stool from the rectum.

Concepts.definition: The use of fingers to evacuate stool from the rectum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of a neodymium-doped yttrium-aluminum-garnet laser to treat posterior capsule opacification following cataract surgery.
